awd_titl_txt: Planning: ADAPT in SC: AI-enabled Devices for the Advancement of Personalized and Transformative Healthcare in South Carolina
awd_abstract_narration:
The ADAPT in SC project will build capacity in the design of biomedical devices with AI enabled, customized performance and secure their manufacture in South Carolina. This initiative focuses on establishing a statewide collaboration which will harness and realize the potential in the state for integrating AI into the design of accurate devices of diagnoses, smart surgeries, and precision rehabilitation. The proposed planning grant will be used to fund three meetings comprising a series of dialogues among ADAPT in SC participants and stakeholders. These meetings are anticipated to refine the ADAPT in SC team’s understanding of the state of the art in fundamental AI science and its application in biomedical devices; the state of the art in education, training, and workforce development in the fields of AI and biomedical device design; and stakeholder perceptions of social, commercial, and economic factors affecting acceptance and adoption of AI techniques and AI-enabled devices.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The activities funded by this NSF EPSCoR Planning Grant fostered collaborations from within and outside the jurisdiction by bringing together the ADAPT in SC team with stakeholders from the research, education, workforce development, industry, and healthcare arenas to provide their individual expertise in support of fundamental advancements in AI. Three main activities were sponsored in addition to two strategic planning sessions and one team science workshop.

An Education and Workforce Development virtual webinar held in January 2022 helped the team identify gaps in education and workforce development specifically related to AI-enabling biomedicine and biomedical devices. Those gaps included both tangible and intangible infrastructure resources as well as ideas and opportunities to address the identified gaps. The outcomes of this activity guided the team in developing educational opportunities for students in K12 through post-graduate levels.

An AI in Medicine Symposium virtual webinar was held in February 2022 and helped the team identify strengths, weaknesses and gaps in the AI effort and ability. The inventory of gaps in skills and abilities and ideas on closing the gaps and ways to sustain the efforts across the jurisdiction guided the team in further developing educational and research activities in the full RII Track-1 proposal.

A Stakeholder Roundtable was held virtually in March 2022 and brought together the external affairs teams from the comprehensive research universities, industry, and healthcare leaders within the jurisdiction as well as international companies who have existing AI in healthcare interests. These individuals were able to provide insight on workforce development needs including gaps in skills for new hires from all levels of expertise, ethical and other areas of concern for the population of our geographically, politically, and racially diverse jurisdiction. The outcomes of this activity were educational opportunities through internships, research opportunities through industry-funded project ideas and soft commitments, as well as ideas on sustainability of the project efforts beyond the initial stages.

A strategic planning session was held in Columbia, SC in March 2022 bringing together collaborators from three CRUs, five predominantly undergraduate institutions (PUIs), three Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs) and our SC EPSCoR office. This activity refined the unifying vision for ADAPT in SC, summarized necessary capacity building elements to achieve competitiveness, and drafted the initial logic model. A follow-up strategic planning sessions was held in July 2022 in Columbia, SC to further develop ideas on the management plan and team dynamics as well as continued discussions on resource needs and data sharing opportunities.

A Team Science Workshop was held in Clemson, SC in May 2022. This activity hosted a resident Team Science Expert to guide the team through the development of communication and collaboration practices in support of developing the team?s management plan for the full proposal. This activity also fostered relationships between colleagues from the twelve organizations involved in the project.

This grant provided opportunities to the ADAPT in SC team to receive input from various stakeholders who brought to the table concerns and ideas that the team had not initially considered. Having this information in the planning stage of the proposal submission was vital to preparing well-informed and unified ideas for increasing capacity in our jurisdiction from K12 educational opportunities to advancements in healthcare to expand access to potentially life-saving screening for the rural communities in South Carolina.
